Award.AwardTitle: Representation Theory, Number Theory, and Invariant Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the conference "Representation Theory, Number Theory, and Invariant Theory," taking place June 1-5, 2015 at Yale University, New Haven, CT. Representation theory of Lie groups is a central subject in current mathematics. The theory is motivated on one hand by physics and on the other by the theory of automorphic forms, with deep roots in classical analysis and with strong ties to differential equations. Thanks to the diversity of motivations, goals, and methods involved, it has broad applications to a variety of branches of mathematics, bridging many areas.

The conference will review the role of representation theory in various disciplines such as automorphic forms, harmonic analysis, and invariant theory developed over the past half a century, present recent progress in this field, and chart future developments in the subject. The meeting will feature lectures from world experts, discussion sessions among participants, and problem sessions. The broad spectrum and great current interest of the topics will make the conference inspiring for young mathematicians and stimulate further progress in the field. A volume of proceedings, intended to make these results more accessible and applicable, will be produced. Additional information can be found at the conference website: http://web.mit.edu/juleekim/www/Howe70/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference ``Representation Theory, Number Theory and Invariant Theory" took place June 1-5, 2015 at Yale University, New Haven, CT in time for Professor Roger Howe's 70th birthday. The aim of the conference was to overview the role of representation theory in various disciplines such as automorphic forms, harmonic analysis, and invariant theory developed over the past half a century, present recent progress in this field, and finally aim to extrapolate it into future. The main topics included automorphic forms, invariant theory, representation theory of reductive groups over local fields and related subjects. Professor Howe's work and insights have been most influential in the development of these fields of mathematics. The conference was in particular timely as it covered recent developments. There were 22 hourly talks and discussion session between talks during the 5 day conference. 21 talks were filmed and they are available at http://math.mit.edu/conferences/howe/lectures.php

We have been also working on editing the conference proceedings "Representation Theory, Number Theory and Invariant Theory: In Honor of Roger Howe on the occasion of his 70th birthday". We expect the volume will be published in a series "Progress in Mathematics", Birkhauser, Springer by the end of the current year. Once published, we expect it will be a valuable asset to researchers working in this field.

The grant also supported participants in various other conferences including the AMS meeting special session "Representations of Reductive Groups", Rutgers University, New Brunswick in November 2015, and  2016 Midwest Representation Theory Conference which was held in honor of Phil Kutzko's 70th birthday, University of Iowa.
